awd_titl_txt: A Computational Modeling Approach to Organizational Effectiveness: Mapping the Effects of Leadership, Group Structure, and Environmental Shocks.
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description

The project is a three-year program of basic research designed to address gaps in theory on team leadership, team composition, and adaptability to environmental shocks, with a specific emphasis on multi-team systems (MTS). This project extends our prior work on emergent phenomena in teams by applying computational modeling to an extended network of MTSs. The goal is to design a highly flexible computational agent architecture that can be applied to a broad range of team types (e.g., action, project, decision-making teams), task structures (e.g., pooled, sequential, reciprocal, intensive), and MTS contexts (e.g., military, medical, business). The computational model will be used to conduct virtual experiments to evaluate the effects of different team composition and leadership configurations on team (Phase 1) and MTS (Phase 2) effectiveness, and the resilience and adaptability potential of different configurations given internal and external shocks (Phase 3). This modeling research has many practical applications. In particular, it is designed to identify the basic mechanisms that underpin team effectiveness.  The model can then be used to predict the effectiveness of particular team and MTS configurations and, based on those findings, provide prescriptive principles for composing teams, and appointing team leaders, to ensure that teams and systems of teams are optimized for effectiveness. 

Technical Description

The emergence and dynamics of phenomena relevant to the effectiveness of team and MTSs has proven difficult using the dominant research methods (experimental and correlational research) employed in organizational psychology and behavior (OPB). A "third discipline" based on computational modeling is needed if OPB is to advance understanding of process dynamics. The development of a comprehensive computational model, based on a Markov Decision Process (MDP) architecture, which incorporates team composition, leadership structure, and process mechanisms within- and between-teams, will mark a significant advance in OPB.  A key advantage of computational simulation is the ability to systematically and thoroughly map a theoretical space.  Virtual experimentation will enable specification of the fundamental mechanisms that drive dynamic interconnections among leadership, team structures, and member composition ad their sensitivity, resilience, and adaptability to internal and external shocks. Moreover, our use of the MDP "engine" will enable specification of optimality and deviations from it. Research findings will enable subsequent empirical research to be more precisely targeted, with specific points for intervention identified.  The formal computational model will enable the generation of generalizable predictive forecasts of the effectiveness of various team and MTS leadership structures under different within- and between-team conditions. Thus, recommendations from this research are intended to enhance the gains of subsequent empirical research in terms of both efficiency (i.e., focusing on promising targets, avoiding research that is less likely to be productive) and effectiveness (i.e., focusing on interventions that are more likely to be successful). This is vitally important because research on teams and MTSs is highly resource intensive. By more precisely targeting at human research based on the findings of virtual experiments, the resources invested in human research are likely to have a much higher return. Thus, this research has the potential to aid funding agencies to more precisely target research funding priorities.  Moreover, the research has a wide range of potential applications.  This same flexibility permits examination and quantification of how adaptive and responsive different system configurations would be to unexpected shocks.  As a result, decision-makers would have the predictive and prescriptive tools from which to make informed decisions about critical personnel, team structure, and organizational design decisions.

por.por_cntn:
The environment in which organizations operate has continued its trajectory towards increasingly more complex demands that require rapid, flexible, and adaptive responses. In response, the last two decades have witnessed a world-wide restructuring of work around teams. Team-based structures permit multiple individuals to simultaneously coordinate individual efforts by capitalizing on team members’ unique resources. Moreover, systems of teams have begun to emerge as a new organizational form - multiteam systems (MTSs). Consequently, enhancing MTS effectiveness hinges on understanding the dynamic forces that influence how individuals within and between teams interact to combine their efforts successfully.

Maximizing organizational effectiveness in such systems depends on achieving three key outcomes. First, individuals and teams with diverse characteristics need to work together effectively. Teams and MTSs are often composed of members with diverse individual and sociocultural characteristics. This highlights the importance of melding diversity and minimizing the potential for fragmentation. Second, leadership needs to align individual behaviors with team and MTS outcomes. The desire for organizational resiliency necessitates a shift in emphasis to teams as a focal point for skill development and action – to move decision-making closer to problems, decrease response times, and enable diverse expertise to be flexibly applied to critical tasks and emergent crises. This places primary emphasis on leadership functions both within and between teams. Finally, teams and MTSs must be capable of absorbing unforeseen shocks. In turbulent environments, goals, resources, and even the members of teams and MTSs can change suddenly and unexpectedly. This means that members must be able to bond, integrate, and perform in compressed timeframes. Achieving these three key outcomes entail critical research challenges that must be surmounted if desired levels of organizational effectiveness are to be realized.

The purpose of the research effort is to address these challenges through theory development (i.e., a precise computational model [CM] incorporating key theoretical mechanisms), instantiation of the CM in an agent-based simulation (ABS; i.e., a computer simulation), and research to establish the generative sufficiency (i.e., appropriateness) of the CM/ABS. The CM/ABS can then serve as a platform for a series of virtual experiments designed to identify effective team and leadership designs that are adaptive to unforeseen internal and external shocks.

The project has developed a highly flexible CM/ABS that incorporates three primary modules: (a) task interdependence structures (i.e., how individuals are interconnected in a workflow), (b) person characteristics (i.e., surface [demographics] and deep [personality] individual differences of team members), and social characteristics (i.e., team cohesion, mutual influence including leadership). The model has been subjected to preliminary studies to establish its generative sufficiency (i.e., that it generates results that are consistent with theory and findings from extant empirical research). Longer term, ongoing investigations will identify configurations of team composition, leadership processes, and MTS configurations that enable teams and MTSs to adapt to unforeseen shocks.

In addition to advancing the theoretical and methodological sophistication of system- and dynamic process-oriented research in the organizational sciences, the CM/ABS developed in this research has substantial application potential. Within certain boundaries, an effective CM/ABS can be tuned to emulate a specific MTS or organizational system. That is, with appropriate observations using real world data, the parameter values of the CM/ABS can be aligned with a target system. The CM/ABS can them be used to conduct prescriptive research that contrasts the current system design (i.e., baseline) with theoretically driven or pragmatic alternatives to identify alternative system designs that maximize particular criteria (e.g., designs that are robust to shocks, designs that adapt well to shocks, etc.). Thus, CM/ABS research has substantial application potential for improving organizational effectiveness.
